title: 104_s265
content: The Act may be cited as the "Bisti/De-Na-Zin Wilderness Expansion and Fossil Forest Protection Act". It pertains to the Bisti/De-Na-Zin Wilderness. The San Juan Basin Wilderness Protection Act of 1984 is amended to designate the Bisti/De-Na-Zin Wilderness as part of the National Wilderness Preservation System. The San Juan Basin Wilderness Protection Act of 1984 is amended to designate the Bisti/De-Na-Zin Wilderness in New Mexico as part of the National Wilderness Preservation System, comprising approximately 16,674 acres. The amendment includes specific details on the designated lands and timelines for implementation. The San Juan Basin Wilderness Protection Act of 1984 is amended to designate the Bisti/De-Na-Zin Wilderness in New Mexico as part of the National Wilderness Preservation System. The lands described in subsection (a)(3) are withdrawn from mining laws and mineral leasing, with provisions for coal leases in exchange for preference right applications. The Secretary confirms the applicant's preference right lease and deems the exchange as being in the public interest. Operations on oil and gas leases issued before the enactment of subsection (a)(3) must adhere to regulations to prevent disturbance of land surface and ecological values. Amendments are made to allow exchanges for State Lands under the San Juan Basin Wilderness Protection Act of 1984. Amendments are made to allow exchanges for State Lands under the San Juan Basin Wilderness Protection Act of 1984, with specific timelines and requirements outlined for different subsections. The San Juan Basin Wilderness Protection Act of 1984 is amended to allow exchanges for Indian lands held in trust for the Navajo Tribe by the Bureau of Indian Affairs within a specific boundary area. The lands will be exchanged for lands of equal value in New Mexico selected by the Navajo Tribe, and after the exchange, the selected lands will be held in trust by the Secretary of the Interior. SEC. 3. FOSSIL FOREST RESEARCH NATURAL AREA. Section 103 of the San Juan Basin Wilderness Protection Act of 1984 is amended to establish a Fossil Forest Research Natural Area. The Fossil Forest Research Natural Area, spanning 2,770 acres in New Mexico, is established to conserve natural values, provide scientific knowledge, education, and interpretation for future generations. The Secretary of the Interior will file a map and legal description of the Area with relevant committees. The map and legal description of the Fossil Forest Research Natural Area will have the same legal force as if included in the Act. The Secretary of the Interior can make technical corrections to the map. The map and legal description will be available for public inspection. The Secretary will manage the Area to protect its resources. The lands within the Area are withdrawn from all forms of appropriation under the mining laws and from disposition under all laws pertaining to mineral leasing, geothermal leasing, and mineral material sales, subject to valid existing rights. The Secretary of the Interior is authorized to issue coal leases in New Mexico in exchange for any preference right coal lease. The Secretary of the Interior is authorized to issue coal leases in New Mexico in exchange for any preference right coal lease application within the Area, subject to applicable laws and regulations. Oil and gas leases issued prior to the date of enactment are subject to specific provisions and conditions determined by the Secretary to avoid any conflicts. The Secretary of the Interior will develop an inventory of fossil resources within the Area and conduct monitoring surveys as per the management plan. Livestock grazing will not be permitted in the Area. The Secretary of the Interior will develop a management plan for the Area within 5 years of the Act's enactment, outlining appropriate uses and cooperative programs for education about the resources. The management plan for the Area will include provisions for vehicle management, excavation and collection of fossil remains, and mitigation standards for activities that disturb scenic and environmental values.
